title: 110_hr4308
content: The Act may be cited as the "NASA Innovation Fund and Sponsorship Act of 2007". It includes a section on the NASA Innovation Fund. The "NASA Innovation Fund" is established in the Treasury of the United States, funded by charitable donations or program proceeds. Funds can be used for advertising and administrative expenses, with limits on expenditures set by appropriations Acts. The Fund may be used for administering the prize competition under section 314 of the Act, with any remaining amounts used for prizes. The Secretary of the Treasury will invest excess funds in interest-bearing obligations of the United States, which may be acquired on original issue or by purchase, and sold at market price. The Fund allows for the sale of obligations at market price, with interest and proceeds credited to the Fund. NASA INNOVATION FUND SPONSORSHIP ADVISORY COMMITTEE. The NASA Innovation Fund Sponsorship Advisory Committee is established within NASA to advise on program implementation. The committee consists of 5 US citizens with expertise in education and promotional activities, appointed by the Administrator. Members serve staggered three-year terms. The Advisory Committee members serve staggered three-year terms. If a member leaves before their term ends, a successor may be appointed to serve the remainder of the term. Members cannot serve on the committee for more than 6 years. They are not compensated for their services but are reimbursed for necessary expenses. The committee meets regularly. The Advisory Committee meets at least 4 times a year, with the Administrator and Chief of Strategic Communications of NASA or their designees present to offer guidance. Additional meetings may be called by the Administrator. SEC. 4. INNOVATION FUND SPONSORSHIP PROGRAM. The Administrator is authorized to create an Innovation Fund Sponsorship Program allowing individuals to use the Partnership Logo in exchange for a monetary contribution. A sponsor is a person approved to participate in the program. The logo will include the words "NASA Innovation Fund Partner" and an image chosen by the Advisory Committee. To become a sponsor, a person must submit an application to the Administrator. To become a sponsor in the Innovation Fund Sponsorship Program, an individual must submit an application to the Administrator. The application should include the amount to be contributed to the Fund and a detailed description of the promotional program using the Partnership Logo. The program should focus on promoting educational programs and opportunities in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics. The Innovation Fund Sponsorship Program requires approved applicants to enter into a sponsorship agreement with the Administrator, providing a specified amount and allowing the use of the Partnership Logo in their promotional program. Restrictions include no logos on spacecraft and no astronaut endorsements in advertisements. The Innovation Fund Sponsorship Program requires sponsors to provide a specified amount and use the Partnership Logo in promotions. Restrictions include no astronaut endorsements in advertisements and protection of proprietary information. Congress encourages NASA to participate in authorized activities. The National Aeronautics and Space Act of 1958 authorizes assistance to sponsors for promotional programs using the Partnership Logo. Enforcement includes civil actions and penalties for unauthorized use of the logo in promotions. The Administrator can take legal action against sponsors for unauthorized use of the Partnership Logo in promotional programs. An annual report to Congress includes actions taken by NASA, financial statements, and an evaluation of the Innovation Fund Sponsorship Program. The Advisory Committee consults with NASA Centers annually. The Advisory Committee consults annually with NASA Centers, including Ames Research Center, Dryden Flight Research Center, Glenn Research Center, Goddard Space Flight Center, Jet Propulsion Laboratory, Johnson Space Center, Kennedy Space Center, Langley Research Center, Marshall Space Flight Center, and Stennis Space Center, to improve the authorized program. SEC. 5 of the National Aeronautics and Space Act of 1958 is amended to include the NASA Innovation Fund and Sponsorship Act of 2007. SEC. 6 defines terms like Administrator, NASA, Partnership Logo, and Promotional program.
